"Because of the inactive lifestyle and stressful life, many people are receiving lifestyle illnesses such as diabetes, hypertension, etc. The Fit India Movement can encourage people to eat healthy foods and maintain physical and mental fitness."

"With high-quality ads and marketing practices, junk food manufacturers are manipulating children to buy their food. This Fit India Movement will make children think about the negative consequences of junk food. As a result, this movement will encourage children to eat healthy foods."

"Some parents put too much stress on children to study. They send their children to classes after school or simply make them sit down to do their homework forgetting the importance of free time to play. This movement has the potential to change its mind and as a result, they can encourage their children to go out and play."

"This movement has the potential to make more people embrace traditional forms of Indian martial art such as Kathi Samu, Musti Yudha, etc., and traditional forms of dance and also healthy Indian sandwiches. And as a by-product, this may result in the creation of some jobs."
"Motivation to maintain fitness must begin from childhood. But in India, many schools lack playgrounds. The lack of playgrounds can push children to resort to inactive lifestyles."

"The ‘Indian Movement’ may not reach people below the poverty line. To maintain a healthy lifestyle, both physical activity and nutritious foods are needed. But in India, many people are still undernourished and some people do not have access to safe drinking water. Therefore, without resolving the problem of poverty and the lack of access to affordable nutritious food, a sector of the Indian population will not be able to take advantage of this movement."

"Some people are already focusing on physical fitness. We can observe this with the increasing number of fitness startups. But that's a small proportion of people. Usually, many people want to keep an active lifestyle, but all they need is a little encouragement. Therefore, this movement constantly reminds people to focus on fitness goals like Swachh Bharat reminds us of the importance of keeping our environment clean."

"Since the invention of machines, the value of workers is decreasing. They're built to work to support the machines. As a result, work revolves around machines and not humans. Workers are forced to work continuously with the machine. "

"People are now getting involved in the trolling and cyberbullying. Hiding behind devices is giving them the courage to harass other people, which may not be done face to face. This is the deterioration of moral values."

"Some companies are building strategies to use their apps longer, to keep us addicted to their apps and devices so they can show us ads. And they can also use our data to manipulate our decisions for their profits. These strategies are turning humans into just targets."

"Industrialization increased working hours. Workers face inhumane conditions. Humans cannot work and focus continuously as machines. Quick until today, we have technological devices to check how many hours we really work. Some companies want to be connected 24 hours a day through emails and messages. This makes people feel less human."

"Our decision-making skills are also being affected, as we are now asking search engines to know what's best. We rely on the Internet knowledge base even at the offices to finish the job by hand. This affects cognitive abilities (thinking, reading, learning, remembering, and reasoning), which is an essential quality of human beings."

"Many face-to-face communications are also replaced by virtual interactions. Many people now live in virtual homes, which is the smartphone. As the need to speak to one another is diminishing, the ability to communicate with one another, which is a basic quality of living beings, is diminishing."

"We are increasingly dependent on the technological devices that guide us. For example, we keep reminders on smartphones and google questions for answers. We are outsourcing activities that require technology intelligence. Thinking, remembering things, and analyzing are essential qualities of humans. Too much dependence on technology is making us less human."

"Using technology, people are maintaining and improving relationships with their friends, family and relatives. Many people also connect with each other to help those in need and inspire each other. Therefore, we now have better tools to build human connections."

Technology allows us to work from home. This service is helping employers to be more understanding with employees. Many companies are now adding elements to work culture with the help of technology to make employees feel important.

"This bill confers exclusive powers on the National Research Agency (NIA). NIA can take anyone into its custody under UAPA without prior permission from the state government. This is against federalism, which is guaranteed by the constitution of India."

"The labelling organizations as terrorist organizations and individuals as terrorists are very different. If a person receives the name of a terrorist, he or she will face social exclusion and lack opportunities to earn a living even if he or she has shown otherwise. The consequences will be irreversible. For example, only in 2016 67% of cases ended in acquittal, which means they are probably innocent."

"If someone is registered under the UAPA, the burden of proving their innocence lies with them. This new amendment is allowing the government to confiscate its property. So how will they pay the legal expenses to prove their innocence, if they are falsely accused?"

"This will provide more police powers to the central government. The designation of persons as terrorists may be misused. For example, recently several civil activists are called Naxals Urbanos. If anyone opposes the government, he will be vulnerable to being framed as a terrorist. Because this amendment made it easier to label someone as a terrorist."

"There is a growing threat of lone wolf terrorism. Lone wolf terrorists have no association with terrorist organizations, but they commit terrorist attacks alone. This new amendment to the UAPA has the potential to curb lone wolf terrorism."

“To prevent human rights violations, a four-stage review is added. India does not initiate the designation of persons as terrorists. The United States, the European Union and China also have this provision."

"So far, organizations were only designated as terrorist organizations, but not as individuals. The gap in this is that the individuals of the banned organizations are forming new organizations and carrying out terrorist activities. This draft law amending the Law on the Prevention of Unlawful Activities allows the Government to designate persons as terrorists, so terrorist attacks can be prevented."
"It is necessary to act firmly against terrorism in the midst of the increasing threats of terrorists. Therefore, it is necessary to strengthen the UAPA."

"At present, India does not have a well-developed infrastructure to ensure data security. Moreover, developed countries already have an efficient infrastructure. Therefore, rushing toward data localization may not be a wise step. Because without efficient infrastructure, data is prone to cyber attacks. And the risk is serious here because it's financial data. But as laws are made, it is a great challenge to develop an efficient infrastructure at a faster pace."

"Data storage in India means higher operating costs for payment system operators. Because in other countries they have cheaper alternatives. And also for cross-border transactions, they have to store data in two locations, which increases costs. There is a likelihood that these additional costs may have an impact on consumers."

"Data localization laws lead to the creation of multiple data centres at the local level. This will create many jobs and help the country's economy immensely. It will also drive innovation on the ground, leading to low-cost solutions."

"In investigating offences, payment data will need to be accessed. If the data are stored abroad, it is very difficult to obtain permission from that country to access the data. This causes delays in the resolution of crimes. If the data is stored here within our country, this problem will be avoided."

"India is a large consumer market for many foreign companies. Thus, India and other developing countries are realizing the economic value of data and the importance of data localization. With data localization, national companies and the country's economy will benefit. And we can also guarantee data security."

"The data is considered a 'new form of wealth'. In general, companies use data to understand consumer requirements and also to influence their behaviour. New products can be developed by analysing data to meet the needs of consumers. So the data has an economic value. In general, developed countries are taking advantage of this opportunity with their well-developed infrastructure. "

"We are in a globalized world. Today, the world is functioning with the free flow of people, goods, services and data. Data localization laws appear to be part of protectionist policies, which threaten the free flow of data."

"U.S.A. is against data localization laws. Recently at the G20 summit, Donald Trump, the president of the United States spoke out against data localization. Its stance is natural because it increases the operating costs of American companies. Bilateral relations India-US are important for both countries because we are intertwined in the export and import of IT services, professionals and goods, etc. Therefore, imposing data localization laws without threatening Indian-American relations is another challenge."
We can guarantee the privacy of the data by locating the data.
Data tracing can lead to government surveillance of its citizens.
"Data localization is important for data sovereignty, which means that citizens' data must be owned by the respective governments and not by other countries."

"The law is very clear in the sense that RTI not only deals with government bodies. It is also the responsibility of non-governmental organizations that are substantially funded and controlled by the Government. There are numerous subsidies (including tax exemptions) available to political parties and are therefore substantially funded by the Government."
"Political parties are independent bodies, they do not have to be accountable to the public. They were not established by the Constitution or by a law of Parliament."

“The IRR Act provides that, wherever there is a public interest, such organizations must be transparent and subject to the scope of the law. There are a number of private organizations today, whether partially funded or fully funded; schools, hospitals, etc. which are under the Anti-Terrorism Act and not just governmental organizations."
There are adequate provisions in the Income Tax Act and with the Electoral Commission to enable individuals to have the information they want.

“Article 8 of the IRR Act contains provisions mentioning the concept of competitive interest. Certain exemptions are provided for in cases where it can be proved that disclosure of information may prejudice the competitive advantage of the party. This is not only a problem with political parties, but also with many governmental and private bodies."

"Political funding is believed to be the source of corruption. Citizens have the right to know where political parties come from to raise these funds, how they spend them and the basis of their decisions. Capitalism Crony will be greatly restrained if political parties are brought under the RTI Law."

"Under the IT Act, political parties do not need to disclose donations they obtain below INR 20,000. An informal study conducted in 2010 on 6 key political parties shows that Rs 700 crore increased. Ninety-five per cent of the amount was collected for amounts less than Rs 20,000. There is a great possibility that political parties will take advantage of this gap for their benefit."
"The political parties declare certain promises in their manifestos. After being elected, citizens have the right to know why the promises made by political parties were not fulfilled."

"Political parties are fundamental to the functioning of democracy. Political parties continue to form the government. The policies of the government are then governed by the ideology of the party. It is therefore essential that political parties fall under the scope of the ITR."

"If political parties enter under the RTI, it will affect their internal functioning. Rivals can use RTI to malign each other. Moreover, since political parties are not directly connected to the public, an IRT would be invalid."

"The Indians as a whole consider educational institutions as working machines, we hope to go into unemployment and get out of employment. We do not realize that we will have to improve our skills to become job-worthy. This is why more than 80% of engineers are unemployable and the figures are even worse for non-engineers."

" Although we have been establishing institutes nationally for the past 40 years, we have not been investing to maintain their standards. Funding is needed for quality education. Even the main Indian institutes lack adequate infrastructure, laboratories, resources, etc. And even what is available is only for the sake of passing students on the exam and sitting inactive for the rest of the time."
Today no problem has a single solution and no new technology is related to a single discipline. We need multiple contributions from multiple disciplines and our institutes have failed to do so.
"Indian students act brilliantly when they go to different countries in the field of research. It means we don't lack talent, we lack infrastructure and a healthy environment for our sharp minds."

"We have not been paying our teachers on the scale of what their counterparts earn in other countries. As a result, people are reluctant to the idea of teaching as a career. Nor have we succeeded in attracting successful foreign faculties to our institutes."

"Achieving excellence in anything takes time. Through graduation, students gain so much knowledge in the relevant field. It is therefore easier for employers to train these students for industrial requirements."
Any skill can be learned and mastered even if we don't have a title in that. And programming is no exception.

"Even if someone has a degree in IT, they have to learn a lot to get into IT work, because there is a gap between industrial standards and the skills taught at engineering universities. Moreover, as technology is constantly evolving, even if someone has prepared for industrial standards at graduation, they have to learn new technologies continuously to remain relevant in the labour market. Therefore, as the learning curve will be there even for IT students, students from non-IT backgrounds can also learn these things and can enter IT jobs."

"The number of IT jobs is increasing at a rapid pace due to the technological revolution. There will therefore be more jobs in the field of information technology. And if recruiters are very strict about grade, they can lose a large talent group, which are from a non-IT fund."

"Now, we have so many online course platforms through which we can learn almost any skill from experts. We can also obtain certificates if we pass the tests. So, as Tim Cook said, a 4-year title looks old and traditional."

"In many of India's engineering faculties, we can easily pass the subjects even if we don't have much knowledge in those subjects. That is why many companies are not able to find the right talent, even if there are so many eligible graduates. Therefore, the will to become an expert in the field is more important than a title. "
"If a non-IT student decides to start a career in the IT field, the efforts they put into graduation will go in vain."

"Although the new programming languages are replacing the old ones, the basic concepts are the same for almost all programming languages. Therefore, the one who has a coding degree will have an advantage over the student of a non-IT fund."

"People change careers even after working in a field for several years because our interests change. Therefore, when someone can do this while having so many personal responsibilities, it is much easier for young people to learn a new skill."

"Variable remuneration definitely increases employee productivity. High-performing people feel well compensated and rewarded for their efforts, while low-performing people also feel motivated to improve."

"In variable pay schemes, employees are satisfied and motivated by their work. They feel an active part of the organization, the organization recognizes them as part of its growth and values its efforts."

"Variable remuneration helps to retain valuable employees. This helps to retain good talent for long periods of time and, therefore, to spend less on hiring new talents. This provides stability to the organization."

" It has been shown that it is difficult to retain employees in times of scarcity when they are in variable pay systems. Workers who receive commissions do well when the business is good, but they do it wrong when the business is bad. In times of slow business, even top sellers may have difficulty making enough sales to make a decent living. If the market is slow and the workers in charge cannot earn enough, they can look for other employment opportunities. In times of scarcity, fixed wages can be more effective in preventing employees from going for other opportunities."

"Variable remuneration can lead to unhealthy competition between employees. They become less willing to help each other. The cooperation of the team may be adversely affected. In the long term, relations between colleagues can become bitter. Whereas, in fixed pay schemes, employees can maintain cordial relationships in the office."

"Most sales jobs have a variable component. This could negatively affect the employee's attitude towards customers. They can force customers irrationally only to make profits for themselves. They could exaggerate the price to customers just to get more profits. While an employee with a fixed salary would maintain healthy and positive relationships with customers, achieving the right balance in their approach."

"The enormous data we produce every day is analyzed and fed on our devices through algorithms that end up giving more and more control of our lives to gadgets. We can feel that we receive all these services for free, but they come at the cost of our precious time and attention."

"With all the data and algorithms our applications and gadgets, without our conscious knowledge, are making decisions for us. Decision-making is (was) one of the qualities that made human beings different from others."

"After a 10-hour daily shift from Monday to Friday, most of us prefer to stay home on holidays. We surround ourselves with laptops, TV and mobiles and use them in cycles for Netflix, sports, social networks, etc. (thinking we're relaxing) instead of going out. We prefer and are more comfortable with online chat instead of talking to real people. There are fewer significant relationships today due to all the above factors. We have begun to prefer isolation."

"Nuclear technology is a very efficient alternative to non-renewable energy resources. But still, we chose to move forward with more and more types of nuclear warheads. The same is true of almost all other inventions. Similarly, although initially AI promised better lives for us, due to AI, we have begun to lose our basic human qualities."
"We have begun to lose our basic human habits and instincts, and they are actually governed by devices and applications."

As Yuval Noah Harari says, “What we need now is morality and spirituality. Morality consists in reducing suffering in the world. And spirituality consists in questioning and seeking answers. Religions provide us with only answers and no range of questions.”

"Religion has served its purpose to unite people, establish structures in society and develop trust and cooperation. But in the 21st century, we are thriving towards objective realities, and religion is an intersubjective reality and now all it does is create differences in the world, brainwash people, develop animosity for other beliefs, and provide rituals that are just shortcuts to becoming a good person. (A Muslim can pray 5 times a day; a Hindu can pray daily for hours in temples; a Christian can go to church every day, but still be involved in immoral activities.)"

"In the past, every unknown thing was about religious beliefs. But now Science and Technology has taken care of everything. We know the reasons for drought, earthquakes, windstorms, etc. are scientific phenomena and no longer the wrath of the gods."

"Because of their technological nature, neobanks do not need physical banking branches, which helps them save on overheads (the cost of managing the company). Therefore, neobanks can offer customers lower rates and higher interest rates on checking and savings accounts."

"People don't trust neobanks so much because they don't have a physical presence, which makes them a risk to customers in case of any problems or challenges. Customer service in person may seem more reliable to customers."

Technological literacy remains very low in India. Traditional banks can meet the banking requirements of less technologically skilled customers or people in rural areas of the country who prefer face-to-face interaction with the manager.
"Commercial banks help create credit, leading to an increase in consumer production, employment and spending, all of which contributes to the growth of the economy."
"Since neobanks are completely digital, they operate 24 hours a day and their services can be accessed at any time. They are easily accessible from anywhere through a smartphone."

"Fintech companies can open new specialized banks that target a specific type of customer needs. For example, LXME aims to become India's first Neo bank for women, which will offer product solutions that address women's specific financial needs and emotional preferences."
"The 5G in banking will bring much-needed financial inclusion to the rural and remote populations of India, for whom access to a physical bank is not possible."

"The low latency of 5G will allow the inclusion of education in remote areas of India, where children will be able to access good quality education in the home without any gaps in the network between them and their favorite tutor. In addition, 5G will make possible the use of new age technologies such as AR and VR for more immersive learning in schools and schools."

"5G will greatly increase the number of networks that can be connected, handling up to a billion Internet of Things terminals, which will allow machines and humans in a factory to communicate seamlessly with each other, making business more efficient and reducing the possibility of error."

"The government will be able to improve its governance and give a boost to its digital India initiative, which aims to ensure that government services are available electronically to citizens, making the country have digital power in the field of technology."
"Hydrogen is flammable and can cause fires or explosions. Therefore, it is not yet completely safe."
"If hydrogen fuel production uses fossil fuels, it can be counterproductive. Therefore, the use of renewable energy to produce hydrogen fuel is important."

"Hydrogen fuel cell vehicles do not emit greenhouse gases. This helps to combat climate change. As many countries are opting for the energy transition, clean hydrogen fuel vehicles along with other alternative fuel vehicles can pave the way for sustainable transport. Moreover, as these vehicles do not emit greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide, they can greatly reduce air pollution."
"The prices of fossil fuels are continually rising. Therefore, if more hydrogen vehicles enter the market, the price of fossil fuels can reduce."
"Hydrogen vehicles are much quieter than fossil fuel-based vehicles. Therefore, they can also reduce noise pollution."
"If hydrogen fuel escapes into the air, it can increase global warming."

"During the time of the pandemic, social media helped people maintain their social life.Social media made it possible to stay connected with friends and loved ones all the time. We can easily know what is happening in their lives. It allowed us to communicate with multiple people at the same time by sharing messages."

"Because of social media, we now have the opportunity to connect with many people, even if they don't live in our area. Before social networks, we could interact with people from our locality or from the places we go."

"By following friends on social media and not communicating with them in private, we can only know the things they post in their accounts. We may not know much about what is really happening in their lives. That means we won't have meaningful connections with friends. The convenience of contacting people online made us prefer it rather than meet them outside."

"Some people now have social anxiety due to not having enough face-to-face interactions. When we avoid talking to people for a long time, we automatically develop the fear of getting involved in small conversations."
Trolling on social media is a big threat. It is affecting the self-esteem of many people and it is also making them avoid forming social connections.

"In the book "IGen", it was mentioned that in the next decade we could see more young people who know the right emoji for a situation, but not the right facial expression. This can come true if we prefer virtual life over real life."

"Through close communities or micro-communities based on shared social media interests along with private messages, social networks gave us the opportunity to build real connections with people we can really relate to."

"The NEET test standardizes the entry criteria for medical education throughout the country. As a high score is required to enter the government's medical schools, the examination ensures meritocracy."

"But every year, less than 20% of students pass the exam. With this, it is clear that the quality of medical education in other countries where Indian students are studying is not on par with medical education in India. It is therefore very important to take steps to provide affordable, high-quality medical education in India."

"As the exam requires further study, training centers are taking advantage of the situation and are charging lakhs of rupees for training for the NEET exam. Therefore, because of this, students who cannot afford coaching are at a disadvantage."

"Students work hard to score well on class 12 exams, but all that hard work is not recognized. And only the NEET score is considered to enter medical college, which is very unfair. In addition, the NEET examination is mainly based on the CBSE curriculum. Therefore, students on the state board have to study additional things to get a good score on the exam."

"A high score on the NEET exam is required for admission to government medical schools in India. It costs approximately 1.25 million rupees to study in private medical schools in India. Thus, many students are forced to go to other countries such as China, Ukraine, Russia, the Philippines, etc. to continue medical education. In these countries, medical education costs about 35 lakhs of rupees. In addition, they allow students with low NEET scores, but above cut marks."

Some people in the moonlight to pursue their passion when the gains of their passion cannot replace the wages of their main work. Several entrepreneurs take this route and leave their jobs once they earn enough from their new businesses.
"According to a study published by the Academy of Management Journal in 2021, lunar lighting can provide a sense of control and motivation, which can improve employee productivity."

"The sudden layoffs of several companies, especially during the pandemic, caused fear among many employees. And so several people took parallel concerts or a second job as a safety net in case they were fired."

Moonlight can help improve. Some people want to learn new skills apart from what they are working on their main work. This can help you develop your experience in your field. Some might get bored with monotonous jobs and therefore take second job to learn new skills and thus make their days exciting.
Companies fear information and the theft of sensitive data and the possibility of sharing it with their rival companies.

Some managers are concerned that employees who moonlight may not be productive in their main work due to fatigue and increased stress. There are also concerns about working for other companies during the office hours of my main job.

"In general, companies provide various benefits to employees, such as the Provident Fund, Health Insurance, etc. Therefore, they feel it is unfair when their employees focus their energy and time on a second job, which does not provide any of those benefits."

A cashless economy saves so much money for governments because printing money and sending money to banks requires money and human resources. The need to purchase or rent ATM land will also be eliminated. International payments will also be easier because there is no need to exchange currency.
Cashless transactions leave fingerprints of financial transactions. They can be used to track illegal activities.
Pandemia COVID increased the number of cashless transactions. They can prevent the spread of contagious diseases.

"Cashless transactions are recorded by banks. Therefore, the data will reveal people's critical data regarding where they spend money. The government can easily access anyone's data. It can result in mass surveillance programs. This is against the right to privacy. Cash gives us anonymity."
A cashless economy will increase the number of cybercrimes.
Technical problems in banking can stop access to our money. This can interfere with our daily lives.

"Refugees are forcibly displaced. They fled their country for various reasons, such as violence, human rights violations, war, persecution of minorities, etc. They often face threats to life in their countries of origin. They leave their homes and everything else in search of a safer place to live."

"At present, many countries are rejecting refugees claiming that they represent an economic or security threat. Only a few countries, such as Lebanon, Jordan, Turkey and Liberia, are accepting most of the refugees. Some host countries were forcibly sending refugees to their countries of origin, claiming that, for example, the situation in their countries of origin was safe. Many refugees who were thus sent suffered brutal violence and some people even disappeared."

All countries must share the responsibility of refugees. Resettlement of refugees should take place without delay. They should be provided with skills development courses and employment opportunities to help them lead a dignified life.
